today we are tackling meat loaf now meat
loaf is one of America's favorite
comfort foods but often time it's either
bland dry crumbly or a combination of
all three well today I'm gonna share
with you all of the tricks and tips
along the way in making meat loaf and
you will have something that you would

so let's talk about the meat that's the
most important part of a meatloaf now
when you go to your neighborhood grocery
store this is probably what you're going
to find a finely ground meat usually
beef but sometimes there's a blend of
meats you want to make sure that you're
using the right proportions and
proportions are a ratio of meat to fat
now typically sold you have an 80
percent to 20 percent meat to fat ratio
and then there's also leaner versions
that are 90 to 10 percent and you want
to make sure that you avoid that kind of
low range of fats to meat ratio that
90/10 because you really need enough fat
within your meat loaf to keep it nice
and moist and tender now another thing
to think about and if you can do this
you really should maybe you should ask
the butcher in your supermarket to grind
your meat fresh for you and to grind it
coarsely now here in front of me I have
pork and beef that is 80/20 that same
ratio that we're recommending but it's
coarsely ground and you can see how much
texture there is here in this meat
versus what you would get if you bought
a prepackaged ground meat which is nice
and finely ground now the reason I am
encouraging you to get coarsely ground
meat is because that means that it's not
overworked you're going to take this
meat and you're gonna mix it up with all
of the seasonings and flavorings and
finding ingredients and you're gonna
work it together with your hand so you
want to start with something that's a
little bit more coarse because in the
end you will end up with a better more
tender texture to it something that's
not too worked now I'm using a blend of

I have ground pork here
now you could use a combination your

you can even mix that in with your

I'm using an equal ratio so this is a
pound and a quarter of each ground pork

it is a heavily worked muscle and it
works really well here in ground form
because it has a ton of flavor and
you're breaking up the muscle fibers
when you go wrong
so that it will have a nice tenderness
to it in the end so you want to make

something that will keep your meatloaf

I'm using white bread today just regular

could certainly use those the one thing
I would tell you to do is to steer away
from store-bought already ground dry
bread crumbs because those are dry
they're absent of moisture and unless
you really rehydrate them very well
you're going to end up with a dry
meatloaf because all those dry bread
crumbs are going to pull all of the
moisture out of the meat out of whatever
else you're adding into your meatloaf
and ultimately in the end you might end

this to your meatloaf so that's

now one thing that happens with freeform

now I'm gonna go wash my hands really

is tomato and vinegar so it has a nice

using a bristled brush just brush this
